name: virtuality
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ U ] the fact of being created by computer technology and appearing to exist, but not existing in the physical world: In an age of prosthetics, cloning, and virtuality, does authenticity matter? They were confident they could take video games to the next level of virtuality, so that players would feel as if they were actually inside the game. See also
virtual reality
[ U ] the fact of happening or being done using computer technology over the internet, and not involving people physically going somewhere: The virtuality of the forum transformed classroom learning.
[ C or U ] the fact of existing, but not in a way that is physically real, or a thing that is imagined or considered rather than being real: The Greek philosophers believed that perfection only exists in virtuality; any attempt to produce something in reality leads to imperfection. As writers, they constantly seek ways of re-expressing old virtualities. Physicists use metaphors of virtuality to assign values to potential particles.
More examplesFewer examplesHer art installation is poised between concrete reality and virtuality.Virtuality is not new: audio experienced through streaming services is "real", but it is also manipulated as a virtual object in a virtual space.
